awd_abstract_narration:
This grant funds the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site "Complexity across Disciplines" at Boise State University, a nine-week program for eight students each summer.  The program, hosted in the Department of Mathematics, focuses on projects related to computational complexity.  The site seeks to produce cohorts of young researchers whose work and vision transcend traditional boundaries among STEM disciplines.  Each cohort will engage in contemporary research problems in mathematics, with applications to cryptology, biology, and several other fields of inquiry.  The program will also provide opportunities for REU students to participate in outreach activities targeting K-12 students in the region.  Students from rural communities with limited opportunities will have one-on-one exposure to highly motivated STEM students from across the nation. The site offers, in collaboration with other summer undergraduate research programs at Boise State University, a rich array of professional and interdisciplinary development events.

The nature of computing and complexity has expanded from the academic realm to the practical arena through great strides made in the scientific understanding of basic processes of life, significant advances in information processing through the growth of the internet, and automation of basic daily tasks.  The research projects are motivated by a quest for efficient search or sorting algorithms and for efficient information security tools.  The mathematical foundations for these projects include algebraic structures, combinatorial structures, and game theory.  Each project has deep connections with significant open problems in mathematics, and could lead to discoveries of importance to the security of current commercially used cryptosystems and to data mining. The idea of examining certain genomic rearrangement processes from a game-theoretic point of view is new, has inherent value as a mathematical exploration, and has the potential to clarify observed phenomena in natural rearrangement processes.

por.por_cntn:
The REU Site Complexity across Disciplines (REU CAD) was funded by NSF grant DMS 1659872 for Summers 2017, 2018 and 2019. The site received 966 applications and hosted a total of 35 undergraduate students, including three qualified undergraduate international students whose participation was funded by their home institutions or other sources. During Fall 2019 and Spring 2020 the site hosted, under a no-cost extension, four undergraduate students. The participants were affiliated with 24 different institutions nationwide. While 31.01% of the applicants were female, 35.90% of the recruited cohort participating in REU CAD was female.

The site offered in-house professional development events, as well as professional development events co-organized with the Summer Undergraduate Research Community at Boise State University, a consortium of several programs including this REU site. The in-house events included workshops on communicating mathematics to various audiences and workshops on the responsible conduct of research. The jointly organized events resulted in a diverse community of undergraduate researchers and faculty mentors. The site also hosted eleven speakers from Mathematics departments nationwide.

The site strongly promotes developing communication skills towards dissemination of its research projects and findings and towards obtaining funding for research projects. In line with this effort, the site spearheaded founding the Idaho Conference on Undergraduate Research (ICUR). ICUR is open for participation by undergraduate students from all institutions in all disciplines, and for attendance by the public. The site?s cohort of student researchers presented posters at this conference with special attention to presenting to a wide, diverse audience. The site also collaborated with two other REU sites at Boise State University in hosting the REU FORUM in STEM interdisciplinary seminar. At this venue, the REU fellows introduced their peers in REUs from other disciplines to the site?s research projects. The culminating on-site event is the Summer Undergraduate Research Symposium Mathematics. It is open to faculty and students in Mathematics, and to attendance by the public. Recognition of elevated communication skills came in the form of Mathematical Association of America Outstanding Presentation awards to six REU CAD posters presented at the annual Joint Mathematics Meetings in January 2018 and January 2019. Moreover, during the funding period four alumni/ae of the previous site grant were awarded NSF Graduate Research Fellowships.

The site?s public outreach activities under this grant included hosting cryptology workshops for the summer academy of the NASA funded Idaho Science and Aerospace Scholars Program for high schools in Idaho (Summer 2017-2019), and engaging students from the Ada County Boys and Girls club with hands-on activities related to the site?s research projects.

The site?s research program engaged participants in interdisciplinary mathematics-based research projects that advanced the frontiers of knowledge in fields related to information security and genome biology.  In the arena of mathematics inspired by genome biology accomplishments include an extension of prior findings on permutation sorting to the vastly broader fields of graph theory and of linear transformations on finite dimensional vector spaces over finite fields. A closed form formula for the number of sortable graphs on a given number of vertices was discovered and proved, and data findings were deposited at the Online Encyclopedia for Integer Sequences. A novel application of classical results in abstract algebra revealed an extensive taxonomy of the non-sortable permutations. This taxonomy enabled a significant extension of prior game theoretic results related to permutation sorting. A new parameter, the Grundy number of a permutation, emerged from this work.

In the Information security arena: Advances in quantum computing technology precipitated an urgent need for cryptosystems that are secure against the superior computational capabilities of quantum computers. The continued miniaturization of cyber-enabled technologies and their deployment in ever more critical contexts, for example implanted medical devices, is equally driving the urgency for establishing cryptosystems compatible with the resource constraints of small devices and with the security requirements of a cyber connected infrastructure. The National Institute of Standards and Technology is managing the process of determining new post quantum cryptography standards to mitigate the quantum threat, and of determining new lightweight cryptography standards to mitigate the resource constraint threat of critical micro devices. Towards preparing the next generation of mathematicians and domain researchers for the post quantum, post miniaturization world of cybersecurity, several NIST candidates for post quantum and for lightweight cryptography have been investigated at this REU site. The research has made fundamental advances on mathematical problems underlying the security of NIST crypto candidates. Investigations of cryptographic systems have also led to mathematical problems related to the algebraic structures that form the platform for these cryptosystems, and the REU site also made fundamental contributions on these problems.
